Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2014 07:02AM auroaya wrote: I had a port placed in when I was first dx in 2009 with bc stage iia and after the chemo was over they removed. Nobody asked me if I wanted it removed they just did. Then last  year I was dx stage IV while undergoing femur surgery and the anesthesiologist could not find a good vein on my good arm so they finally used the surgery one even though it had a warning not to. They say its because I was loosing a lot of blood and had no time to put in place a central line. In any case there was infiltriation in the IV and they permanently injured my right hand. I am now suing the hospital. This would all have been avoided with a port. I now have a new one and planning on keeping it forever or for as long as it doesnt need replacement. I understand this is an extreme situation and don't mean to scare anyone unnecesarily but if you have hard veins I suggest keeping it in. Aurora
Posts.Title: Port removal for stage 4 ladies??? Iwillwinthisbattle Nel

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2014 04:09PM auroaya wrote: After my unilateral mastectomy in 2010 I flew from Houston to Miami two weeks after the surgery with the drains on. I asked my surgeon and he said it was ok to just keep emptying the drains. I also had lymph nodes removed and developed lymphedema on the right arm but was not told anything about that. In these boards I've read that flying with LE can worsen the LE. You should definetly consult your docs.

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2014 12:48PM auroaya wrote: pg Feeling sad at what we've lost is common for Stage IV patients. In fact, recently the experts have started recommending that oncologists refer all cancer patients to get evaluated for depression and given treatment if need be. I myself take medicine for depression (it's called Cymbalta) and it really helps with my sadness. I also take another medicine called Risperidone which is a mood stabilizer. I'm not a doctor so I can't recommend it for you but I would talk to your doctor and maybe he can refer you to a specialist. Also talking to somebody that understands helps. Feel free to come here often and release your tears on us your sisters, we understand like no others can because we all go through the same emotional roller coaster. I'm sending you (((hugs))) and wishing for your peace. Aurora

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2014 09:22AM auroaya wrote: DanaL I too suffer from depression I was diagnosed with it a few months before my dx for bc and I take anti depressants (Cymbalta 60mg) and mood stabilizer (risperidone 2mg). A few months ago I ran out of insurance and stopped taking them but  continue taking the anti-hormonal Arimidex which is what I take for cancer. The se's of the Arimidex went through the roof! hot flashes, mood swings depression and it all went away when I started taking my psych meds again. The new standard of care is urging oncologists to screen their cancer patients for depression and refer them to a Psiquiatrist when appropriate. Depression is a chemical imbalance and cancer medication and chemotherapy affects that balance (in my opinion) so I would suggest to get screened by a professional and maybe get into some type of medicine. We need our energies to deal with cancer and depression undermines those energies. Hope you can get help. Take care Aurora

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2017 10:19AM auroaya wrote: Hello everyone I see many known faces here! I’ll read the previous posts later I just wanted you to know that I’ve progressed to liver mets after 4 years of bones only. The biggest tumor is 1.4 cm x 6.5 cm and it grew from the last scan. The findings say there are “multiple “ lesions. Leaving Abraxane on to Gemzar. If any of you can help me find the best thread on Gemzar I’d appreciate it if you guide me there. I’m not surprised about the location there were always small shadows there but what got me off guard was how fast they’re growing and expanding. I had a CT scan on September and one last week and there was growth. Fortunately I have no symptoms for neither the bone or the liver mets. Any and all advise welcome. Aurora

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2017 02:59PM auroaya wrote: Z I agree with rpoole get the port! I’ve had mine for four years and it’s a beauty. I use it for scans and blood draws. Like she said make sure it’s a pier port so they can do contrast.. Artist yes I was on Abraxane for close to a year but now the cancer is on the liver 6 cm tumor so doc switched me to Gemzar once a week for three weeks one week off. Abraxane was only every two weeks so I am feeling the effect but I agree with my oncologist I need something strong for now. Reading and praying for each one. Aurora

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2014 05:16AM auroaya wrote: My onc. describes my status as "not active" but when pressed for a more specific dx. she stated in writing: "history of Metastasized Stage IV Breast Cancer" and said that as long as I'm getting treatment she would not change the dx. I have a new scan coming up in August and when I see the onc after the scan I will ask again and ask her if she uses the terms NED or stable.  Like others have said I don't thing Stage IV breast cancer can ever really be in "remission". If I was in the shoes of our TN sisters I would be in permanent anxiety/fear of it coming back. I pray that doesn't happen to any of them.
